Introduction

Retinoblastoma is a rare but life-threatening malignancy of the retina that primarily affects young children.  It is the most common ocular tumor of childhood and often presents with leukocoria in children age <5.

Pathophysiology



Retinoblastoma develops from genetic alterations disrupting the RB1 gene, which functions in cell cycle regulation.  Checkpoints normally occur at the G1/S and G2/M transitions (

figure 1
), allowing the cell cycle to pause for repair of damaged DNA.  The RB1 tumor suppressor gene encodes the Rb protein, which regulates the G1/S checkpoint.  In its active form, the Rb protein binds and inhibits E2F transcription factors, thereby halting the cell cycle.  When the damaged DNA has been repaired, the Rb protein is inactivated by cyclin-dependent kinases, allowing the cell to proceed through the G1/S checkpoint.



A copy of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene is found on each copy of chromosome 13, and normal regulation continues at the G1/S checkpoint if there is at least one functional RB1 gene.  However, if both copies of RB1 are defective, there is unrestricted progression through the G1/S checkpoint, which leads to uncontrolled cell division and tumorigenesis.



Because loss-of-function (LOF) mutations must occur in both alleles of the RB1 gene for tumorigenesis to occur, retinoblastoma is an example of Knudson's 2-hit hypothesis of tumorigenesis (

figure 2
).  Familial and sporadic forms of retinoblastoma can develop depending on how the "hits" occur:



  • Familial retinoblastoma (40% of cases):  A patient can inherit a germline LOF mutation (eg, mutation in one parent's germ cell before conception).  Therefore, at birth, all cells already have the "first hit."  Because there is still one functional copy of RB1, cell cycle regulation is maintained.  A retinal progenitor cell that develops a mutation in the remaining, functional RB1 provides the "second hit" that leads to uncontrolled division.  Patients with familial retinoblastoma often come to medical attention earlier in life and have bilateral disease.
  • Sporadic retinoblastoma (60% of cases):  Patients with sporadic retinoblastoma do not inherit a germline LOF mutation.  Therefore, a single retinal progenitor cell with 2 normal RB1 alleles must acquire 2 spontaneous mutations to become malignant.  Accordingly, these patients often come to medical attention later in life and have unilateral disease.


Because patients with familial retinoblastoma inherit a germline LOF mutation that affects all cells, they can acquire a second LOF mutation in other cells later in life, leading to additional tumors (eg, sarcomas).  In contrast, patients with sporadic retinoblastoma are not at increased risk for other malignancies because the chance of somatic LOF mutations occurring in both alleles of the RB1 gene in different cell lineages is very low.



The primary risk factor for retinoblastoma is young age; approximately 95% of retinoblastomas occur in children age <5.  A family history of retinoblastoma also increases the risk, although this accounts only for approximately 10% of cases (suggesting that the majority of germline mutations occur de novo in a gamete).

Clinical presentation



Retinoblastoma is typically diagnosed in children age <5, particularly age <2.  The most common presenting features include:



  • Leukocoria (
    figure 3
    ) or absent red reflex:  Leukocoria is the most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma and appears as a white pupil in flash photography due to light reflecting off the tumor.
  • Strabismus (
    figure 4
    ):  Strabismus (ie, ocular misalignment) is the second most common presentation of retinoblastoma, occurring as a result of vision loss from tumor-induced retinal detachment.


Less commonly, patients may have nystagmus, decreased vision, ocular pain, erythema (due to intraocular inflammation), or proptosis (a late finding due to tumor mass effect on the globe).

Diagnosis



If there is clinical suspicion for retinoblastoma (eg, leukocoria, absent red reflex, strabismus), diagnostic evaluation should be performed and include:



  • Ophthalmic examination under anesthesia:  This allows for complete visualization of the retina to identify the tumor, which appears as a nodular, off-white retinal mass (
    image 1
    ).
  • Diagnostic imaging:  This allows for assessment of intraocular and extraocular tumor extension, which guides treatment planning.  Imaging may include:
    • Ocular ultrasonography, which may show calcifications.  When present, calcifications are an important distinguishing feature of retinoblastoma.
    • MRI of the brain and orbits (
      image 2
      ), which can evaluate for optic nerve involvement and the presence of a separate, primary intracranial tumor, both of which carry a poorer prognosis.


Retinoblastoma can be diagnosed based on ophthalmic examination and imaging.  Biopsy for tissue diagnosis is unnecessary due to the risk for tumor seeding.  Metastatic work-up (eg, bone marrow evaluation, lumbar puncture, bone scan) is typically not performed unless there is clear evidence of tumor extension beyond the eye (eg, optic nerve invasion).



Genetic testing of peripheral blood to evaluate whether the patient has a germline RB1 mutation should be obtained in all patients to assess the risk of hereditary transmission.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of retinoblastoma includes other conditions that may also present with leukocoria, such as:



  • Persistent fetal vasculature:  a congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete regression of the fetal hyaloid vascular system
  • Toxocariasis:  caused by Toxocara canis or Toxocara cati larvae, causes retinitis and can present with leukocoria and peripheral retinal granulomas
  • Congenital cataracts (
    figure 5
    ):  can occur in certain conditions (eg, galactosemia, trisomy 21, glucocorticoid exposure, congenital rubella syndrome), but examination shows a lens opacity, not a retinal mass


The diagnostic evaluation can help distinguish retinoblastoma from these conditions (eg, the presence of calcification is more likely retinoblastoma).

Management



The goal of retinoblastoma management is to eradicate the tumor while salvaging the eye to preserve vision.  The specific approach is individualized and dependent on multiple factors (eg, extent of disease, visual prognosis, laterality).  Various combinations of the following modalities may be used:



  • Ocular salvage therapy:  Ocular salvage therapy may be considered for early intraocular disease.  Options include:
    • Focal treatment:  Cryotherapy or laser photocoagulation may be performed for small intraocular tumors.
    • Chemotherapy:  For larger intraocular tumors, chemotherapeutic agents can be administered directly via the ophthalmic artery to reduce the tumor volume (ie, chemoreduction).  Chemotherapy may also be given systemically, particularly if there is extraocular disease.
  • Enucleation:  If ocular salvage therapy fails or if there is advanced intraocular disease, surgical removal of the affected eye may be necessary.
  • External beam radiation therapy:  Because retinoblastoma is very radiosensitive, radiation therapy can be used for progressive disease.  However, it is generally avoided due to the risk for long-term complications (eg, second malignancies, bone growth delay).


Following treatment, patients should be monitored for tumor recurrence and long-term complications (eg, vision deficits, secondary tumors).  Genetic counseling is also recommended so that affected families can discuss inheritance patterns and implications for future pregnancies.

Prognosis



The prognosis of retinoblastoma depends on various factors (eg, extent of intraocular involvement, presence of extraocular spread, presence of germline mutation).  If untreated, retinoblastoma is progressive and, ultimately, lethal.  With early detection and appropriate treatment, the overall 5-year survival rate exceeds 95%.  However, long-term sequelae such as vision loss (related to the tumor and/or treatment), orbital/facial deformity, and secondary malignancies (eg, osteosarcoma, soft tissue sarcomas) may impact quality of life in survivors.

Summary



Retinoblastoma (
